title: McCloud River Improved Forest Management Project
tagline: The McCloud River project generates emissions reductions through conservation-based management of commercial timberlands about 20 miles southeast of Mount Shasta in northern California.
project_overview: The project is located 20 miles southeast of Mount Shasta in Northern California. Co benefits such as protection of local water quality and habitat protection for sensitive species are achieved while timber is sustainably extracted to support the local economy. This project covers approximately 9 000 acres and comprises the largest working conservation easement west of the Rockies. It ensures that 15 square miles of forest and 8 miles of the famous McCloud River will be forested and productive in perpetuity. The McCloud River project provides a sustainable and protected habitat for rare, threatened, and endangered species such as the Northern Spotted Owl, Bald Eagle, Roosevelt Elk, and Black Bear. The project also connects to the Shasta Trinity National Forest, providing critical habitat corridors for many species.

project_images.caption: The project supports species such as the Northern Spotted Owl, Bald Eagle, Roosevelt Elk, and Black Bear.
Improved forestry management plays a vital role in protecting freshwater systems like the McCloud River.

leakage.text: As required by Part II, Section H of the CAR FPP v2.1, an activity-shifting leakage assessment was performed and documented within the document 'Annex D - Standardized Questions for Initial Leakage Assessment at Project Initiation'.
leakage.source: Annex D from Standardized Questions for Initial Leakage Assessment at Project Initiation

additionality.text: The project meets the additionality requirements as result of the project activity exceed the GHG reductions that would occur as a result of the baseline scenario. The two tracts that comprise the project area have each been secured with a conservation easement. Each easement requires constraints on forest management activities that are above and beyond those required by the Forest Practice Rules. This restriction on forest management activities will occur in perpetuity, and the project developer has demonstrated, through the use of forest modeling, that such restrictions are likely to lead to increased GHG reductions relative to the baseline scenario. Project activities exceed the applicable mandatory forest management laws used to characterize the project baseline, the project can be determined to be additional in accordance with the Forest Project Protocol. Finally, the Attestation of Voluntary Implementation, attesting that the project has been voluntarily implemented for the duration of the reporting period, has been properly executed by an appropriate representative of the project proponent.

permanence.text: To reflect the duration of project reductions, projects need to demonstrate, through annual reporting, that they maintaining a consistent amount of additional carbon stocks over time. In other words, to demonstrate a consistent amount of reductions, annual calculations should be consistent or demonstrate that a certain threshold of carbon stocks is being maintained by the project. If a year of reporting to the Reserve is missed, any existing reported GHG reductions will be deemed invalid.

verifiability.text: An objective third party—someone other than Pondosa Forest, LLC or the project developer—must be able to look at project data and confirm that the carbon reductions are real and credible. SCS Global Services acted as the third-party verifier in this project since 2011, who determined the proper baseline for greenhouse gas reductions and verified that the reductions adhere to strict monitoring and reporting standards.
